emerging_technologies.name: AI-Driven Smart Contracts
emerging_technologies.description: Contracts that automatically execute based on AI decisions and blockchain validation.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Increases trust and efficiency in transactions but raises concerns about AI bias and legal enforceability.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Regulatory acceptance, legal frameworks for AI in contracts, and security improvements in blockchain technology.

emerging_technologies.name: Decentralized AI Governance
emerging_technologies.description: A decentralized system where stakeholders govern AI development and deployment decisions.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Promotes transparency and reduces monopoly control over AI, but could lead to governance inefficiencies.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Stakeholder education, maturity of blockchain governance models, and public trust in decentralized systems.

emerging_technologies.name: Blockchain-verified Autonomous Decisions
emerging_technologies.description: Autonomous systems make decisions that are verified and logged on a blockchain for transparency.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Enhances safety and accountability in autonomous operations but increases complexity and potential system vulnerabilities.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Regulatory compliance, technology integration in existing systems, and public perception of autonomous technology.

emerging_technologies.name: Space Resource Tokenization
emerging_technologies.description: Tokenization of space resources like asteroid minerals, enabling ownership and trade.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could revolutionize space economy but poses significant legal and ethical challenges.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: International space law, economic models for space resources, and technological feasibility of extraction.

emerging_technologies.name: Tokenized Cognitive Enhancements
emerging_technologies.description: Enhancements in cognitive abilities are tokenized, allowing for secure trading and ownership of cognitive upgrades.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Might create a new class divide based on cognitive enhancements; ethical and privacy concerns.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Bioethical considerations, regulatory acceptance, and public perception of cognitive enhancement.

mainstream_technologies.name: Decentralized Energy Grid
mainstream_technologies.description: A fully decentralized grid where energy production and consumption are managed via blockchain.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Widely adopted in regions with high renewable energy adoption; still facing regulatory hurdles elsewhere.

mainstream_technologies.name: Zero-Knowledge Applications
mainstream_technologies.description: Applications that allow data verification without revealing the underlying data, enhancing privacy.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Integrated into most blockchain platforms, widely used in finance, healthcare, and identity verification.

epoch_themes.description: The shift towards decentralized systems in governance, energy, AI, and beyond.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Encourages democratization of technology, but challenges include security, efficiency, and regulatory adaptation.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Increasing public demand for transparency, privacy, and control over personal data.

epoch_themes.description: Leveraging blockchain for AI transparency, security, and decentralized decision-making.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Enhances trust in AI systems, but also raises issues regarding data privacy and AI ethics.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Growth in AI ethics discussions, push for explainable AI, and integration of AI in regulatory compliance.
